fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • In a leader yesterday we reported that the family solicitor of a British man who claimed to have been tortured in Bangladesh wrote to the then foreign secretary, David Miliband, alleging that MI5 had exchanged information about the detainee, Gulam Mustafa, with Bangladeshi authorities. To clarify, MI5 is the responsibility of the home secretary rather than the foreign secretary (British intelligence on the rack, page 34). • A travel piece about Brno in the Czech republic mistakenly described Spilberk castle as a Unesco world heritage site; on the web version of the piece, an editing error put the castle 30 miles from the city. Pegas was described as a new hotel brasserie; rather, it is a long-time fixture but newly refurbished and reopened (Czech out the prices, 19 June, page 5, Travel). • Nicolas Sarkozy has been president of France for three years, rather than two (Sarkozy faces the cameras to dismiss donation 'lies', 13 July, page 14). He assumed office in May 2007. • Homophone corner: "The mineral-rich rivers also feed the fertile planes that attracted Mayan farmers across the border from Guatemala in the fifth century …" (Grand central, 10 July, page 8, Travel). The Guardian's policy is to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please give the date, page, or web link.
